links.title: America's closest Asian allies are all pushing for stronger ties - with India
links.description: As Washington and Beijing fight out their trade war, Asia's most developed countries are trying to reduce their dependence on China - and turn toward India. Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Australia - all close allies of the United States - are among the countries attempting to diversify their economies away from dependence on China, whose export-oriented industries are likely to be hurt by the trade war.

links.title: Apple's Trillion-Dollar Market Cap: Cramer's 'Mad Money' Recap
links.description: You've probably already heard the news Thursday that Apple ( AAPL) has become the first company to reach a market capitalization of $1 trillion. But Jim Cramer told his viewers that despite today's valuation milestone, shares of Apple still have a lot more room to run.

messages.body: Don't Get Comfortable: Cramer's 'Mad Money' Recap (Wednesday 8/1/18) $AAPL http://dlvr.it/QpQDZ4

links.title: Don't Get Comfortable: Cramer's 'Mad Money' Recap
links.description: Until there's a clear winner in the trade war with China, Jim Cramer told his viewers, investors should expect a lot more volatility in the stock market. The forecast, he said, is still likely to be delicious gains followed by maximum pain.

messages.body: Should Retirees Invest in the Tech Sector? $AAPL http://dlvr.it/QpQDQ5

links.title: Should Retirees Invest in the Tech Sector?
links.description: Volatile tech may not be best for every retiree. For some retirees though, working around the volatility may prove to be worthwhile. "While it's unlikely that we would recommend anyone, retired or otherwise, to place all their bets on tech or any sector, there are certainly circumstances where technology for a retiree could still make perfect sense, particularly as part of a well-diversified portfolio," said Jane Leung, managing director and CIO of Scenic Advisement.

links.title: Histogenics and MEDINET Sign Agreement for NeoCart in Japan
links.description: Histogenics (HSGX) entered into an agreement with MEDINET to develop and commercialize NeoCartÂ® cell therapy in Japan. Terms include a US $10MM upfront payment to HSGX, with ~$77MM in potential milestones and future royalty payments. The activity supports HSGX's plans to expand its territories in Asia and Europe in 2018.

links.title: Histogenics
links.description: Adam Gridley, President and CEO Waltham, MA (NASDAQ: HSGX) Histogenics is a leader in the development of restorative cell therapies that may offer rapid-onset pain relief and restored function. Histogenics' lead investigational product, NeoCart, is designed to rebuild a patient's knee cartilage to treat pain at the source and possibly prevent the progression to osteoarthritis.
